name: biochar
description: Biochar is the solid material obtained from the thermochemical conversion of biomass (for ex. olive tree branches) in an oxygen-limited environment and is a form of charcoal, made of carbon and ashes, remaining after the pyrolysis of biomass. It is a stable solid and can endure in soil for thousands of years. Biochar is treated in the UHA/CNRS laboratory using cold plasma to enrich it with nitrogen molecules and transform it into soil amendment. The important question in research is: what biochar is?
indexInput: Biochar is the solid material obtained from the thermochemical conversion of biomass (for ex. olive tree branches)

name: mobility
description: (EPICUR Alliance)
indexInput: (EPICUR Alliance)

name: what biochar is?
description: In the ePICNutrients project it is important to have some questions in mind: what is biochar from different perspectives? What is biochar as a material? How is it produced? and what attributes are important (as granulometry or extreme surface)? What is biochar in plant cultivation? Is biochar a solution to recycle biowaste in a sustainable (sustainability) way? What is it as a social concept?
indexInput: What is biochar from different perspectives? What is biochar as a material? How is it produced?

name: granulometry
description: Biochar granulometry is a measurement of the size distribution of biochar particles. Different methods of biochar production and treatment result in different sizes of biochar particles. Granulation level is not connected with quality of biochar for the project: using smaller particles improves resolution of extreme surface measurements done in the UHA/CNRS laboratory but when using bigger particles the resolution of extreme surface measurements rapidly falls. Moreover, mixing biochar with sufficiently large grains with the soil means that the physical properties of such a mixture (e.g. greater aeration) must be taken into account in the plant growth process.
indexInput: Biochar granulometry is a measurement of the size distribution of biochar particles.

name: extreme surface
description: For the project the extreme surface is considered as what laboratory equipment like XPS can access (around 10 nanometers) of the surface.
indexInput: For the project the extreme surface is considered as what laboratory equipment like XPS can access of the surface.

name: nitrogen
description: Nitrogen is essential for plant growth, as it is required to make both amino acids (for proteins) and nucleic acids (for DNA), and is used in the correct development and functioning of chlorophyll, thus being vital for photosynthesis. All this means that if nitrogen is lacking, plants will grow more slowly, have lower product yields, and be more susceptible to attack, disease and death. (plasma reactor, nutrients, cold plasma)
indexInput: Nitrogen is essential for plant growth.

name: cold plasma
description: Cold plasma is generated when electrical energy is applied to a gas, causing the ionization of the gas to generate very reactive molecules and ions. It can be used to enhance the biochar. In that process biochar is “washed” (plasma treatment) with a mixture of nitrogen and hydrogen cold plasma.
indexInput: Cold plasma is generated when electrical energy is applied to a gas.

name: laboratory
description: What is the laboratory in ePICNutrients project? In some cases, the answer is obvious - a laboratory understood as research infrastructure can be indicated at the University Haut-Alsace (UHA/CNRS), Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (AuTH) or Adam Mickiewicz University (AMU). This, however, does not exhaust the concept of a laboratory. Thanks to one of the key concepts for the project - mobility - our research space remains in constant motion - spatially, culturally and socially.
indexInput: A laboratory understood as research infrastructure

name: olive tree
description: The olive tree is a perennial, evergreen tree, with its height ranging from 5 to 20 meters. Olive trees grow mainly in temperate and subtropical zones, where conditions are more favorable. One such place is (Crete), where there are over 290,000 olive trees and a population of about 635,000 inhabitants. The annual production of olive oil on the island ranges between 80,000 and 120,000 tons. The olive oil industry generates by-products (olive tree pruning) that can have a negative impact on the environment when not processed in a sustainable (sustainability) way.
indexInput: The olive tree is a perennial, evergreen tree

name: sustainability
description: Main concept of ePICNutrients project and one of main goals of EPICUR Alliance.
indexInput: Main concept of ePICNutrients project

name: soil
description: Soil is a material composed of five components: minerals, living organisms, soil organic matter, gas and water. The development of plants growing in it depends on its physical properties (pulpness, aeration), chemical properties (presence of certain chemical elements) and biological properties (presence of bacteria and other microorganisms). Mixing improved biochar with the soil improves the physical properties of the soil (as possibly evidenced by the results of the small pot experiment on the ryegrass ) and provides the necessary nutrients.
networkArray: small pot experiment on the ryegrass
indexInput: Soil is a material composed of five components: minerals, living organisms, soil organic matter, gas and water.

name: plasma reactor
description: Plasma reactors generate and sustain the cold plasma. The plasma is suspended above the biochar sample surface with the help of an electromagnetic field within the chamber. It can be used to produce plasma treated biochar.
indexInput: Plasma reactors generate and sustain the cold plasma.

name: nutrients
description: Soil is a major source of nutrients needed by plants for growth. The three main nutrients are nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) and potassium (K). Together they make up the trio known as NPK. Other important nutrients are calcium, magnesium and sulfur. Plants also need small quantities of iron, manganese, zinc, copper, boron and molybdenum, known as trace elements because only traces are needed by the plant. (small pot experiment on the ryegrass)
networkArray: small pot experiment on the ryegrass
indexInput: Soil is a major source of nutrients needed by plants for growth.

name: small pot experiment on the ryegrass
description: The interaction of biochar with soil nitrogen cycling in agricultural soils was tested in fertilized and unfertilized soils (control) The purpose of the experiment was to test the interaction of biocarbon with the nitrogen cycle in agricultural soils. Plants - ryegrass (L. perenne) - were grown in small pots containing fertilized and unfertilized (control) soil. In the samples containing soil with added biocarbon, the amount of plant biomass obtained was higher than in the samples not containing biocarbon. The results of the experiment suggest a positive effect of biocarbon on the plant growth process. (soil bacteria)
indexInput: The interaction of biochar with soil nitrogen cycling in agricultural soils was tested in fertilized and unfertilized soils

name: ryegrass
description: Lolium perenne, common name perennial ryegrass, is a grass from the family Poaceae. It is native to Europe, Asia and northern Africa, but is widely cultivated and naturalised around the world. It grows well in most conditions, is easy to manage and, as a perennial, will grow for many years. It also grows fast, which is important in the case of experiments with different kinds of soil.
indexInput: Lolium perenne, common name perennial ryegrass

name: ePICNutrients
description: The project aims to create a collaborative framework for scientists from various fields to develop an innovative soil amendment (biochar) using raw waste materials. It will also examine social aspects of scientific practice, including interactions between humans and non-human elements. A digital media environment will be created to visually represent the temporal, spatial, ecological, and cultural changes involved in trans-European scientific collaboration.
indexInput: The project aims to create a collaborative framework for scientists from various fields to develop an innovative soil amendment using raw waste materials.

name: EPICUR Alliance
description: EPICUR, the European University Alliance, is among the first generation of European alliances piloting a new way to intensify cooperation between higher education institutions through the creation of the European University. The EPICUR alliance aims to foster and develop increasingly close cooperation between academics, students and administrative staff, with the goal of becoming a full-fledged federation of universities (by 2026), offering a truly European experience in learning, training and research. To this end, EPICUR aims to achieve a sustainable federal structure that supports long-term structural transformation and strategic integration (ePICNutrients).
indexInput: EPICUR, the European University Alliance

name: UHA/CNRS
description: Experiments including treating a biochar in the plasma reactor (plasma reactor) and the physical analysis of the biochar were carried out on Univeristy of Haut-Alsace/CNRS (EPICUR Alliance).
indexInput: Experiments including treating a biochar in the plasma reactor (plasma reactor) and the physical analysis of the biochar were carried out on Univeristy of Haut-Alsace/CNRS.

name: AuTH
description: Experiments related to agronomics and biology (small pot experiment on the ryegrass) were carried out at the Aristotle University in Thessaloniki (EPICUR Alliance).
networkArray: small pot experiment on the ryegrass
indexInput: Experiments related to agronomics and biology (small pot experiment on the ryegrass) were carried out at the Aristotle University in Thessaloniki (EPICUR Alliance).

name: AMU
description: Main task of laboratories in Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań (EPICUR Alliance) is to create an experimental media to present produced academic knowlegde (tempography).
indexInput: Main task of laboratories in Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań is to create an experimental media to present produced academic knowlegde

name: Crete
description: Crete is the largest and most populous of the Greek islands located about 100 km south of the Peloponnese. Given the predominance of the olive industry on the island, recycling waste in a sustainable way is crucial for the region (sustainability).
indexInput: Crete is the largest and most populous of the Greek islands located about 100 km south of the Peloponnese

name: olive tree pruning
description: The purpose of prunning olive trees is to open more of the tree up to sunshine. The parts of a tree that are in shade will not produce fruit. The pruning process produces large amounts of waste in the form of leaves (OTL) and small twigs, and larger branches (OTB). Abandoning this waste can lead to the development of microorganisms and fungi that are dangerous to trees.
indexInput: The purpose of prunning olive trees is to open more of the tree up to sunshine.

name: OTB
description: Olive tree branches burning is a common agricultural waste management practice after the annual pruning of olive trees from November to February. In ePICNutrients project we propose to manage biowaste by transforming branches into biochar, which can be used again in agriculture
indexInput: Olive tree branches burning is a common agricultural waste management practice after the annual pruning of olive trees from November to February.

name: OTL
description: Olive tree leaves - OTL - account for about 25% of all bio-waste. They are mainly used as animal feed and in biomass production, but due to their polyphenolic composition, olive leaves have potential in numerous other applications in sustainable way (sustainability). More information
indexInput: Olive tree leaves - OTL - account for about 25% of all bio-waste.

name: soil bacteria
description: Microbes in the soil are directly tied to nutrient recycling especially carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and sulfur. Bacteria are a major class of microorganisms that keep soils healthy and productive (bacteria/biochar interaction).
indexInput: Microbes in the soil are directly tied to nutrient recycling especially carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and sulfur. Bacteria are a major class of microorganisms that keep soils healthy and productive

name: bacteria/biochar interaction
description: One way to assess the impact of cold plasma treatment on biochar and soil is to analyze the growth of bacteria that feed on nitrogen. The larger the colonies of these bacteria, the higher the nitrogen content on the surface of the biochar (increasing nitrogen uptake), and thus the greater the potential for using the treated biochar as a soil amendment.
indexInput: One way to assess the impact of cold plasma treatment on biochar and soil is to analyze the growth of bacteria that feed on nitrogen.

name: increasing nitrogen uptake
description: A key question for the project is the feasibility of using biochar as a way to introduce nitrogen into the soil in a controlled manner. The experiments conducted provided data, the analysis of which allows us to assess the feasibility of this solution (data analysis).
indexInput: A key question for the project is the feasibility of using biochar as a way to introduce nitrogen into the soil in a controlled manner.

name: data analysis
description: lorem ipsum (laboratory) (limitations of experiment) (what is the role of biochar)
networkArray: what is the role of biochar
indexInput: lorem ipsum

name: production of biochar
description: Biochar is most often found as a commercial product, which is produced either by companies that dispose of agricultural waste or industrial waste. Companies offer biochar with different physical and chemical parameters depending on customer expectations.
indexInput: Biochar is most often found as a commercial product, which is produced either by companies that dispose of agricultural waste or industrial waste.

name: industrial waste
description: The industrial waste used to produce biochar comes from factories that use hardwood and other organic materials that can be pyrolyzed. The source of the waste should be carefully documented so that the entire process is sustainable (source information).
indexInput: The industrial waste used to produce biochar comes from factories that use hardwood and other organic materials that can be pyrolyzed.

name: source information
description: Information about the origin of the waste is provided by commercial companies in the form of European Certificates, which specify both the parameters and chemical composition of the waste. This information is crucial for the use of biochar (data management). At the same time, it is important data in the context of the ePICNutrients project.
indexInput: Information about the origin of the waste is provided by commercial companies in the form of European Certificates, which specify both the parameters and chemical composition of the waste.

name: data management
description: Data management depends both on the formats in which the data is produced and used, but also on political and legal regulations in individual EU countries. Some data may be stored only in a specific form or on a specific medium. One way of representing data in an accessible way is this tempography. The form of data management significantly determines how the data is analyzed (data analysis).
indexInput: Data management depends both on the formats in which the data is produced and used, but also on political and legal regulations in individual EU countries.

name: what is the role of biochar
description: A very significant question that the project is trying to answer is the role that biochar plays in the soil once added. Depending on many factors, such as the origin of the biochar, the way it is produced and processed, or the amount of biochar added to the soil, biochar can manifest different aspects of itself (as vessel) (as reservoir) (as soil amendment) (as pollution).
indexInput: A very significant question that the project is trying to answer is the role that biochar plays in the soil once added. Depending on many factors, such as the origin of the biochar, the way it is produced and processed, or the amount of biochar added to the soil, biochar can manifest different aspects of itself.

name: as vessel
description: Biochar can be seen as a vessel for nutrients - by selecting the right source of origin and processing it, biochar can be used to introduce appropriate substances into the soil. It is important that the nutrients in biochar are available to the plants, rather than being encapsulated in biochar particles (as reservoir).
indexInput: Biochar can be seen as a vessel for nutrients - by selecting the right source of origin and processing it, biochar can be used to introduce appropriate substances into the soil

name: as reservoir
description: Biochar particles can act as a reservoir, accumulating and locking up nutrients, preventing access to them by plants and bacteria. In this case, adding biochar to the soil can have the opposite effect of enriching the soil - biochar can absorb substances like a sponge.
indexInput: Biochar particles can act as a reservoir, accumulating and locking up nutrients, preventing access to them by plants and bacteria.

name: as soil amendment
description: Biochar particles affect soil (soil) not only because of their chemical composition, but also because of their physical properties. The size of the particles (granulometers) results in greater aeration of the soil, which has a positive effect on plant growth.
indexInput: Biochar particles affect soil not only because of their chemical composition, but also because of their physical properties.

name: as pollution
description: Large amounts of biochar in the soil can be seen as a pollution that will eventually lead to plant death. Conducting research over a very long period of time - e.g. 50 years - is impossible within the project (limitations of experiment), which should be taken into account when assessing the use of biochar as a soil amendment from a sustainability perspective.
indexInput: Large amounts of biochar in the soil can be seen as a pollution that will eventually lead to plant death.

name: limitations of experiment
description: The experiments conducted within the project are intended to provide a so-called proof of concept - proof that the proposed concept can be applied in the future. For this reason, the parameters of the experiments are significantly limited both in terms of scale and time frame. Clear definition of these limitations allows for more precise data management.
indexInput: The experiments conducted within the project are intended to provide a so-called proof of concept - proof that the proposed concept can be applied in the future

name: tempography
description: This tempography is a way to show the process of creating scientific knowledge, taking into account the various factors influencing this process (translation of knowledge). It is an experimental medium that allows access to the project assumptions and actions taken within it. Its non-hierarchical structure allows for free exploration and searching for issues and threads of interest to each user. At the same time, tempography is a research tool that has enabled communication between researchers from different disciplines and dynamic design of actions taken.
indexInput: This tempography is a way to show the process of creating scientific knowledge, taking into account the various factors influencing this process.

name: plasma treated biochar
description: The main object of experiments undertaken within the project is plasma treated biochar - biochar that is subjected to the action of cold plasma. As a result, changes occur on the surface of biochar molecules (changes in biochar surface), thanks to which they potentially become a valuable addition to the soil. Due to the scale of the project, small amounts of biochar were subjected to the action of cold plasma (limitations of experiment).
indexInput: The main object of experiments undertaken within the project is plasma treated biochar - biochar that is subjected to the action of cold plasma.

name: changes in biochar surface
description: Under the influence of cold plasma, the extreme surface of biochar particles is changed - both chemically and physically. As a result, nitrogen molecules are attached to the biochar pieces (increasing nitrogen uptake), which can be introduced into the soil and have a beneficial effect on plant growth.
indexInput: Under the influence of cold plasma, the extreme surface of biochar particles is changed - both chemically and physically.

name: translation of knowledge

indexInput: lorem ipsum
